threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

threads.com:
I love super mario world. Ive been playing it since I was a kid, I play it at least once a year, It will always hold a dear place in my heart. But it kills me that I'll never play it for the first time again. The main gameplay of SMW is good, its objectively fun, controlling yoshi or grabbing shells or flight is a joy, but half the emat of the game is exploring each nook and cranny for secret exits or new areas. Star road, switch palaces, shortcuts through castles in inch wide gaps. The jumping and movement feels great, it really does, but games like DKC2 clearly have more that it asks of the player, from precision jumping to timing to navigating fast moving areas. Which is fine, world is still fine on its own. But the simple platforming of world just doesnt complete the whole package, and finding those secrets If eel is the missing ingredient.

But Ive done all 96 exits, + star road, plus the ghost houses, plus top secret area..I know where they all are. I can never wonder again whether taking this key over there or flying up to the ceiling might uncover some secret exit or area Ive never seen before. And that kills me inside

They fucked up the chance to make it finally good. They blew the budget on improving things no one asked for (voice acting) or didn't need to be improved (music) - instead of working on things that actually matter (sprites) or improving the actual gameplay/balance. As a result, they had to do shit like using super ugly (but cheap) upscale or outright cut stuff (random encounters, TP, rogue) and replace anything remotely resembling, you know, tactics, with pure RNG gimmicks like buff cards and autoproc skills. To say nothing of adding other dumb shit, dumbing down the mechanics and taking away even more control/customization from the player.
They did fix the most outrageous fuck ups of the PSP version (class leveling, crafting, Deneb recruitment) but it's still a net loss in the end. For what it's worth, the modding potential is higher than on the PSP, though. Cheat Engine already fixes what's easily fixable (so not the sprites nor 4 skill/spell slots).

The only difficult part I had with the game was an obstacle on Metropolis, where you have to jump over a pit, onto a conveyer belt that slows you down, with metal presses on the top that will crush you before you get to the other side.
Eventually I figured out you can just spindash over the entire thing, you don't have to dick around jumping over and trying to make it through by running.
The water pit in Chemical Plant was really fucking annoying when I was a kid.
Wing Fortress was difficult, but mostly only because I rarely made it that far, and it wasn't completely clear which way to go. IIRC you have to do a jump from the turret of a Clucker to barely reach the ledge where you have to go to, and it was very difficult to reach that high. So I always just suicided onto the propeller to lose my rings, and go in that direction on the floating platforms. It probably annoyed me because I'm afraid of heights and the only real way to die on the stage was falling off the ship. But it wasn't "difficult", just different - that stage didn't have the standard dynamic of running - little platforming - running, it was more like a Sonic 1 level with lots of platforming and death traps.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9432336
PS2 games use official drivers like CDVDMAN and CDVDFSV to load from the disc. Any game should work from USB if you patch those drivers.
PS1 games can access the disc drive directly. To load from USB you would need too patch every game separately, but that's not practical.
Most slim PS2s have an emulation layer in place between the CPU and the disc drive, so it may be possible on those by patching the emulation layer. But those models have shit compatibility.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
It's the game that sold PCs as gaming machines.
Before Doom, PC gaming was a niche because PC gamers themselves were few, as PCs were still very expensive and mainly used as office machines, at that time also they couldn't compete with consoles in terms of graphic and speed; most of PCs still used CGA, few EGA and their audio was limited to an internal bleeper, as audio cards were for professionals and costed 1/3 of a machine.
Doom was the right game at the right time. It came out when PC hardwares knew a considerable technical improvement thanks to the new 486 and early Pentium processors and the new VGA and Soundblaster cards, at the same time their prices started to drop more and more. To buy a $3000 machine just to play some point and click in 16 colors (often with no audio) was a laughable idea, but $1000 to play 3D games at 256 colors with stereo sound, well, was an option, still expensive, but evaluable. It was a revolution, and Doom became its symbol; at some point its freeware release were installed on 1 computer out of 2. Doom was more popular than Jesus Christ.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
SNES was kind of cool and innovative hardware for 1990. Underpowered in general, yes, but with interesting technical gimmicks for a home console. Like compare with 2D cartridge based powerhouses Neo Geo or CPS2 (I don't compare with specific multi CPU arcade hardware like Sega Super Scaler because those are way more expensive and in another league entirely)
- Rotation effects. None on Neo Geo and CPS2, Mode 7 on SNES.
- Scaling. None on CPS2, only shrinking on Neo Geo, both shrinking and enlarging on SNES via Mode 7 (although only BG layer)
- Transparency. None on Neo Geo and CPS2, averaging transparency, substracting transparency, addition transparency (something N64 is not capable of, lmao) on SNES.
- Real audio DSP - the first in home consoles. CPS2 also has one, but not Neo Geo.
Now Neo Geo has power where it actually matters - overclocked CPU and large ROM size which let it brute force some of the best graphics and sound in 2D games, but it was way more conservative and safe bet from hardware standpoint. I am not arguing which one is better overall, of course SNES can't compete for the most part. My point is that SNES tried to innovate home console hardware and I respect that.

>>9428243
I just finished getting everything set up, here was my process:

1. Get a memory card with FMCB. You can either install via burned disc and USB, or do what I did and just say fuck it and get one pre-configured off of eBay. Get a second blank memory card, one you don't plan on using, to make a backup of the FMCB card in case anything fucks up.
2. Get an Ethernet module, a real one, not the fake chinese crap. Install a IDE -> SATA converter.
3. Hook up the hard drive to your PC and use WinHIIP ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pO5DmaXKZ0c ) to install a PS2 boot record onto the drive.
4. Either install games during the previous step using WinHIIP, or HLDG via Ethernet ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=noFFANmw8-k )
5. Play some damn games

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Well, I posted about beating Actraiser 2 a few weeks ago, but this was on Normal with passwords. I have now beaten the game 4 times, with two of the times with passwords on hard and lastly one more time on hard with a full playthrough.

After all the blood, sweat, and tears, this has become on of my favorite SNES games. I love the music, the level designs (for the most part) and the combat. Especially the combat! I'm not very good at the combat but I have had a taste of the "balancing of i-frames and enemy hitstun" combat you see the top players do and damn it's satisfying.

For anyone putting this game off because of the difficulty, I would highly recommend just grinding it out, at-least on normal mode. Yeah it's ridiculously hard and yeah those werebeasts/gargoyles are stupid as FUCK, but there's an amazing game underneath it all.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9430291
Here are some unfair parts (to someone who has now beaten it 5 times)
Industen (1-1): The tree trunk jump with the mud underneath. It's such a stupidly precise jump and failure takes off 16 health out of your 20. You have to walk to the very edge of the first platform to make the jump AND you need to delay your double jump. Ridiculous for the first level of the game.
(1-2): After the snake miniboss there is a specific glide you need to do in order to make it past the spikes. Thankfully the spikes deal very little damage so failure isn't so bad.
(2-2): There's a long jump to pass over insta-kill spikes. Requires a jump similar to 1-1 to make, that is jumping off at the edge + delaying your double jump. Easier to make than 1-1
(3-2): There's an enemy here, the blue maggots, that defy the combat of the game. They charge at you and do not freeze when you hit them. Also gluttony is really hard without magic.
(4-1): There's a part where you have to jump over fire that deals 8hp with goblins blocking your jumps. I just try to get lucky here with spamming attacks and it usually works. Also the platforms are hard to jump on for some reason, you have to land in the middle.
(4-2): Random boulders knocking you into pits. I've never died to this however.
(5-1): There's a part with a crab and a flying flail guy that's just pure RNG if you get through it undamaged or not.
(6-1): There are 3 ways to get through this stage, and two of them are insanely hard that lead to instant death if failed to platform correctly. The third way is a fast secret way that leads to healing + 1up in a swamp. How the fuck would anyone know this?

Most of the above is just trial and error for new players, but I do agree there is some BS in this game. Also Gargoyles are insanely hard and will filter most players.

>>9431249
My memory of my Japanese playthrough is pretty hazy at this point. Some important errors I can remember:
Vincent saying "So Sephiroth knows he was created five years ago?" instead of "So Sephiroth learned the truth behind his birth five years ago?"
Cloud, when explaining to the party about his false self, simply states "I heard this story from my friend Zack." when in reality that line is part of a longer sentence explaining that his false self was an amalgamation of Zack's stories, Cloud's ambitions, as well as Cloud's actual experiences. In that same scene, when Cloud is explaining the difference between SOLDIERs and failures like himself, he says "It has nothing to do with the Jenova Reunion." as its own complete sentence, when it's actually part of a longer sentence explaining that successful SOLDIERs aren't affected by Reunion like the tattoo'd copies and he is.
When Cloud is giving the black materia to Sephiroth, he explains that Sephiroth was summoning him to the crater: "All the anger and hatred I bore him, made it impossible for me to ever forget him. That and what he gave me." The second sentence is supposed to be part of the first sentence, Cloud is saying Sephiroth purposefully made Cloud hate him so that he wouldn't forget him.

Some other things like Cloud changing the way he speaks throughout the game (initial Cloud, Cloud after Sephiroth gets in his head, then Cloud after the lifestream all talk differently) and Red XIII going from sounding like an intelligent adult in front of the party to talking like a little kid in front of Bugenhagen aren't conveyed well, but I can't really fault the translators too much on that.
I can remember some insignificant mistranslations too, and there are a lot of lines that are worded like shit but ultimately don't affect your understanding of the story.

I looked at the new translation once and not in-depth. I got up to the first translation error and it wasn't fixed, so I assumed they didn't know Japanese.

>but this part is subjective as hell

Every other RE port *adds* new costumes, on top of existing ones. RE2 N64 *replaces* costumes for ones which turn the characters into walking ads for the dev company that made the port.

The item randomizer was a good idea on paper but the execution is terrible. For one thing only some of the supplies are swapped, and it's not just the type of item that's semi-randomized it's also the amount of ammo you're getting from them; except that it's WAY too lenient and you can easily end up getting up to 32 grenades from a SINGLE drop. Item randomization should be a fun challenge that forces the player to use weapons differently and force him to think about his supplies differently every time, instead it's basically just gameshark cheat mode and getting drowned in supplies.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: It’s far better than you think
threads.com:
Behold, the Bandai wonderswan. The superior 90s handheld that deserves far more credit than it receives

With a library matching the Dreamcast in number and variety, it’s 200 games cover genres that portable gaming frankly sucked at beforehand.

Here you’ll find some of the best strategy RPGs and fighters handhelds ever had to offer in 99.

Backed by the powerhouse that was square, the console got a lot of big name titles from the developer. Final fantasies, mystery dungeons, and a fucking clock tower- the selection of quality RPGs on the console kicks the shit out of what the gameboy color and NGPC was offering that same year.

Being the first handheld with a widescreen, it made real nice for fighting games and vertical puzzlers.

From pocket fighter to guilty gear, to digimon and one piece, the system has a healthy selection of fun brawlers that play very well on the small screen.

On the note of one piece, the console was notable for its anime tie ins. Bandai was a licensing powerhouse after all.

The system was quite capable too! Handily shitting all over the cpus of the gameboy and neo geo pocket- this was the only system of the 3 that could run a full ass web browser.

Nearly the entire library runs at 75 fps. Why? Idk but it’s quite nice. Games are smooth with lots of animation and fast clean scrolling. Hundreds of sprites dotting the screen without hiccup.
The system is no slouch in audio hardware either. Having a capable synth setup, AND cool ass sample capabilities- it has a sound that when used to full potential reminds me of some neo geo titles.

Despite the device being a properly capable 16 bit handheld for the time, the thing SIPS power. A single AA battery will keep the thing in active gameplay for well over 40 hours. That’s not 40 hours standby- that’s 40 hours of straight gameplay. On ONE battery. Gbc could barely muster 10 on 2 of the things.
This was also a console that only cost about $30 on release.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9430835
>RPGs are bad because if you play in a way that trivializes the challenge they become easy
That's true of every game though. Someone could turn around and tell you they think arcade shmups are the easiest genre of game because they play them with infinite credits and slowdown.
Most of the time when people say you "have to grind" in an RPG you don't. Most challenges in the genre have some kind of elegant or clever solution. It isn't the game's fault if you choose to solve every problem in the slowest and most boring way possible.

Here's a concrete example. In Persona 3 one of the first bosses you fight are these glove guys. The first time I played I really struggled against them and game over'd several times. Now I breeze past them on every playthrough.
The thing that makes them hard is their magic, which is very powerful relative to your party when you meet them. But if you give them the Enrage debuff they lose the ability to cast magic, in exchange for powering up their physical attacks. But you can deal with that problem by using the Orpheus/Apsaras combo spell that quickly heals your own party.
In short, I used one strategy to turn a problem I couldn't solve without grinding into a different kind of problem, then I solved that problem with a second strategy. This is how I play RPGs.
It's likely there are other ways of beating this boss without grinding, some even better than mine.
Next time you run into a boss in an RPG that seems impossible, instead of grinding, try to think your way past the problem instead. You'll probably have more fun, and you might learn why people love the genre so much.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9431161
It's mostly an exercise in teamwork. You don't know where things are at due to the randomized format, and while there's certain sanity checks (For instance, you'll never have someone playing Super Metroid and just flat out unable to progress because he won't get a morphball until 30 minutes into his teammate's seed), a lot of decisions you'll make will need to be based off what your teammate has access to and what he's capable of, along with what game they're playing.

For instance, in a Super Metroid multiworld, one player might get everything they need to sequence break to Lower Norfair, but if they can't make the lava dive due to an issue of skill, then the team will lose time as the player is forced to take the slower, logical route. When a race's finish time is based on the last one finished on a team, this also means players that are "ahead" might decide to make checks that they usually wouldn't make in the hopes they get something that would help their partner: For example, a Varia Suit or Plasma Beam in Super Metroid, not strictly needed in either case to beat the game, but nice to have.

I personally think it's fun, but only when you're playing with teammates of equal skill level--being a veteran player and trying to play with someone new is mostly frustrating since the progression isn't even.
